overview:
## Overview

Typically, a message to a proxy is forwarded to the real object or causes the proxy to load (or transform itself into) the real object. Subclasses of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy] can be used to implement transparent distributed messaging (for example, [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSDistantObject]) or for lazy instantiation of objects that are expensive to create.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy] implements the basic methods required of a root class, including those defined in the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObjectProtocol] protocol. However, as an abstract class it doesn’t provide an initialization method, and it raises an exception upon receiving any message it doesn’t respond to. A concrete subclass must therefore provide an initialization or creation method and override the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/forwardInvocation(_:)] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/methodSignatureForSelector:] methods to handle messages that it doesn’t implement itself. A subclass’s implementation of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/forwardInvocation(_:)] should do whatever is needed to process the invocation, such as forwarding the invocation over the network or loading the real object and passing it the invocation. [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/methodSignatureForSelector:] is required to provide argument type information for a given message; a subclass’s implementation should be able to determine the argument types for the messages it needs to forward and should construct an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMethodSignature] object accordingly. See the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSDistantObject], [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSInvocation], and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMethodSignature] class specifications for more information.

# NSProxy

**Class**

An abstract superclass defining an API for objects that act as stand-ins for other objects or for objects that don’t exist yet.

## Declaration

```swift
class NSProxy
```

## Overview

Typically, a message to a proxy is forwarded to the real object or causes the proxy to load (or transform itself into) the real object. Subclasses of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy] can be used to implement transparent distributed messaging (for example, [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSDistantObject]) or for lazy instantiation of objects that are expensive to create.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy] implements the basic methods required of a root class, including those defined in the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObjectProtocol] protocol. However, as an abstract class it doesn’t provide an initialization method, and it raises an exception upon receiving any message it doesn’t respond to. A concrete subclass must therefore provide an initialization or creation method and override the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/forwardInvocation(_:)] and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/methodSignatureForSelector:] methods to handle messages that it doesn’t implement itself. A subclass’s implementation of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/forwardInvocation(_:)] should do whatever is needed to process the invocation, such as forwarding the invocation over the network or loading the real object and passing it the invocation. [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSProxy/methodSignatureForSelector:] is required to provide argument type information for a given message; a subclass’s implementation should be able to determine the argument types for the messages it needs to forward and should construct an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMethodSignature] object accordingly. See the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSDistantObject], [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSInvocation], and [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSMethodSignature] class specifications for more information.

## Creating Instances

- **alloc()**: Returns a new instance of the receiving class

## Deallocating Instances

- **dealloc()**: Deallocates the memory occupied by the receiver.

## Finalizing an Object

- **finalize()**: The garbage collector invokes this method on the receiver before disposing of the memory it uses.

## Handling Unimplemented Methods

- **forwardInvocation(_:)**: Passes a given invocation to the real object the proxy represents.

## Introspecting a Proxy Class

- **responds(to:)**: Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the receiving class responds to a given selector.

## Describing a Proxy Class or Object

- **class()**: Returns `self` (the class object).
- **description**: A string containing the real class name and the id of the receiver as a hexadecimal number.
- **debugDescription**

## Inherited By

- NSProtocolChecker

## Conforms To

- NSObjectProtocol
